title: Effect of pH on CaF2 solubility

content.question: <math alttext="C a F 2 solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolves in water according to the equation <math alttext="C a F 2 solid is in equilibrium with C a with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 F with a negative 1 charge aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext></mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The value of <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for the dissolution is <math alttext="3.5 times 10 to the negative 11 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>3.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. A student measures the concentration of <math alttext="C a with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> ions in a saturated solution of <math alttext="C a F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> at various pH values and uses those values to generate the graph above. Based on the data, which of the following observations about the solubility of <math alttext="C a F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaF</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is most valid?

choices.label: It does not depend on <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="the molar concentration of C a with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mo>[</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> does not change between <math alttext="p H 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="p H 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

It does not depend on <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="K sub s p is equal to the molar concentration of C a with a positive 2 charge times the molar concentration of F with a negative 1 charge squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, so as <math alttext="the molar concentration of C a with a positive 2 charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mo>[</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> decreases, <math alttext="the molar concentration of F with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> increases to compensate, keeping <math alttext="K sub s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> constant.

It is higher at a lower <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; there are more <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> ions in solution at low <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, so <math alttext="H F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> forms and shifts the equilibrium reaction above to the right.

It is lower at a higher <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; there are more <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> ions in solution at high <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, so <math alttext="H F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> forms and shifts the equilibrium reaction above to the right.

content.answer: It is higher at a lower <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>; there are more <math alttext="H with a positive 1 charge" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> ions in solution at low <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, so <math alttext="H F" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> forms and shifts the equilibrium reaction above to the right.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
